DA4BCI 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Riemannian-Distance-Based Alignment (RD)

    domain_adaptation_riemannian.Rd

    The domain_adaptation_riemannian function computes the Riemannian distance between two covariance matrices (C_source and C_target), then uses an SVD-based Procrustes-like alignment (via a rotation matrix) to map the source domain into the target domain. This approach is often applied in EEG or similar scenarios where covariance-based alignment helps reduce distribution mismatches.

    domain_adaptation_riemannian(
  source_data,
  target_data,
  ridge = 1e-06,
  pinv_tol = 1e-10
)

    Arguments

    source_data

    A numeric matrix representing the source domain, where rows correspond to observations and columns to features.

    target_data

    A numeric matrix representing the target domain, with the same number of columns as source_data.

    Value

    A list containing:

    weighted_source_data

    The source data projected (rotated) to better match the target domain.

    target_data

    The original target data (unmodified).

    rotation_matrix

    A rotation matrix derived via SVD to align C_source with C_target.

    cov_source_aligned

    The covariance matrix of the source data after alignment (approximating the target domain).

    Details

    1. Riemannian Distance is computed as \(\sqrt{\sum (\log(\lambda_i))^2}\), where \(\lambda_i\) are the eigenvalues of \(C_s^{-1} C_t\). Note that this distance is currently computed but not returned.

    2. Procrustes Alignment uses singular value decomposition (SVD) to find a rotation matrix that aligns the principal axes of C_source to those of C_target.

    Examples

    # Make sure the `domain_adaptation_riemannian` function is available,
# e.g., library(DA4BCI) if it's in your DA4BCI package.

# Set random seed
set.seed(123)
# Define parameters for generating source and target data
n_s <- n_t <- 10  # number of samples
fs <- 160         # sampling frequency
t_seconds <- 3    # duration in seconds

# Calculate adjusted sample sizes (rows of the data matrix)
adj_n_s <- n_s * fs * t_seconds
adj_n_t <- n_t * fs * t_seconds

# Generate source (src) and target (tgt) data
src <- matrix(rnorm(adj_n_s * 50), adj_n_s, 50)
tgt <- matrix(rnorm(adj_n_t * 50, sd = 3), adj_n_t, 50)

# Perform domain adaptation
da <- domain_adaptation_riemannian(src, tgt)
Z_s <- da$weighted_source_data  # aligned source data
Z_t <- da$target_data           # original target data

# Load visualization libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)

# Compare distributions before and after alignment
plots <- plot_data_comparison(src, tgt, Z_s, Z_t,
                              description = "Normal")
combined_plot <- grid.arrange(plots$p1, plots$p2, ncol = 2,
                              top = paste("Method: riemannian",
                              "Normal Dist (Another Variant)"))

print(combined_plot)
#> TableGrob (2 x 2) "arrange": 3 grobs
#>   z     cells    name                grob
#> 1 1 (2-2,1-1) arrange      gtable[layout]
#> 2 2 (2-2,2-2) arrange      gtable[layout]
#> 3 3 (1-1,1-2) arrange text[GRID.text.235]
